reasoning: The critique targets one supporting step in Section 3.2: the move from “fat-tailed value-efficiency” to “mostly-great futures are a narrow target on linear views.” If that step failed, it would weaken (but not overturn) the paper’s broader “no easy eutopia” case, since the essay also relies on (i) scale requirements on linear views even without fat-tail exactingness, (ii) the multiplicative/fragility argument in Section 2, and (iii) bounded-view arguments in Section 3.3—so centrality is moderate-low. As an objection, it’s directionally plausible (fat tails + scalable search can make ‘good enough’ easy to find/replicate), but it’s underspecified: it doesn’t model the paper’s key conditioning on limited de dicto optimization pressure, doesn’t show that reachable search processes yield a high probability of landing in the top-value region, and doesn’t address the possibility that fat tails mean a very small measure of configurations capture most value (still ‘needle-y’). Thus it only partially weakens the targeted inference. It is fairly relevant to Forethought’s agenda because it engages a Tier-2-style premise/step (fat tails → fussiness) inside a core Better Futures argument and suggests a concrete needed distinction (“all imaginable uses” vs “reachable under realistic optimization”).
title: "Fat Tails May Expand the Optimization Target"
